sample.title: How This Nano-Bubbling System Captures Bacteria
sample.description:
Scientist Marino Morikawa developed a nano-bubbling system capable of capturing viruses and bacteria as they rise to the surface of polluted water.

Nikolaj Coster-Waldau traveled to Peru to see this technology in action.

sample.title: Inventions That Could Help Heal the Planet  | An Optimist‚Äôs Guide to the Planet
sample.description:
From ancient stone tools to modern breakthroughs, human ingenuity has always helped us adapt and thrive. In this episode of An Optimist‚Äôs Guide to the Planet, Nikolaj Coster-Waldau travels to Peru, Ecuador, the Netherlands and France to meet the bold innovators reimagining nature‚Äôs potential. Whether it‚Äôs reinventing concrete to turn cities into carbon sinks or mining nickel from hyperaccumulating plants, these trailblazers are redefining what it means to build a sustainable future.

An Optimist's Guide to the Planet captures Nikolaj Coster-Waldau‚Äôs search for people across the globe who are helping drive humanity toward a brighter, more sustainable future. Watch more: https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLqq4LnWs3olWjrbUW6iwUu-_fsJd2sc9c

sample.title: Can Mamdani Win Over Wall Street?
sample.description:
Zohran Mamdani pulled off a historic win in New York City‚Äôs mayoral race with a litany of promises aimed at making life more affordable for residents. The 34-year-old Democrat handily defeated former New York Governor Andrew Cuomo and Republican Curtis Sliwa. He‚Äôll be New York‚Äôs first Muslim mayor and the first person of South Asian descent to lead the city in its 400-year history. Now, Mamdani faces the challenge of making his campaign pledges a reality and winning over skeptics, including Wall Street. Mamdani also may have to contend with President Donald Trump, who has already pledged to punish the city for choosing a self-described democratic socialist. 

0:00 Introduction

3:44 Mamdani‚Äôs proposals

sample.title: Why Americans Are Suddenly All In On Thrift Clothes
sample.description:
At ThredUp's 600,000-square-foot warehouse in Suwanee, Georgia, roughly 40,000 pieces of used clothing are processed each day. The resale company's logistics network, four facilities across the U.S., now rivals that of some fast-fashion giants. The global secondhand apparel market is expected to reach $367 billion by 2029, growing almost three times faster than the overall global apparel market. For years, Gen Z shoppers have been driving the rise of secondhand fashion. Now, rising prices and new tariffs announced by the White House earlier this year are pushing even more Americans to follow their lead. CNBC got a behind-the-scenes look at ThredUp‚Äôs operations to learn more about how new AI tools and tariffs are boosting America‚Äôs secondhand market.

00:00 Introduction
1:44 ThredUp's resale machine 
3:24 When tariffs hit fashion
5:33 AI and the future of shopping

Produced, shot and edited by: Lisa Setyon
Edited by: Andrea Miller 
Narration: Ryan Baker

sample.title: The Truth About AI And The Mass Layoffs
sample.description:
Between January and September 2025, there have been 946,426 job cuts announced, with roughly 300,000 from the government sector, according to Challenger, Gray & Christmas. But some economists don't buy that recent layoffs are caused by AI. Economic uncertainty, tariffs and less consumer spending might be hurting U.S. workers more than CEOs will admit.

sample.title: Are city-run grocery stores a good idea?
sample.description:
Grocery prices in U.S. urban areas have tripled over the past 40 years, straining household budgets, according to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Zohran Mamdani, the Democratic winner of New York City‚Äôs mayoral primary, is proposing city-owned grocery stores to "keep prices low, not make a profit." These are not new concepts in the U.S. and have been tried in the past.

CNBC visited two smaller cities in Kansas to see how this model operates and whether it could be replicated in larger cities.

sample.title: Why this price tag could bring surge pricing to groceries
sample.description: Electronic shelf labels, digital screens that display the price of an item, are replacing traditional paper price tags in grocery stores across America.

sample.title: Why Stellantis Is Pouring $13 Billion Into A U.S. Comeback
sample.description:
Stellantis, the Euro-American parent of Jeep, RAM, Dodge and Chrysler, is forking over $13 billion to fix its money-losing U.S. business, which is responsible for more than half of Stellantis's total profits. Formed in 2021, the company was a star--every year made more money than the one previous. But all the while, customers were walking away. Here's what it is trying to do to get them back, and what challenges remain.

00:00 - Introduction
1:23 - Model merger 
4:12 - U.S. turnaround 
6:31 - A move to gas vehicles 
7:42 - Challenges 

Produced by: Robert Ferris
Edited by: Darren Geeter
Animation: Mallory Brangan, Jason Reginato
Senior Managing Producer: Tala Hadavi

sample.title: Criminal network behind UK mini-marts enables migrants to work illegally, BBC finds | BBC News
sample.description:
A Kurdish crime network is enabling migrants to work illegally in mini-marts on High Streets the length of Britain, a BBC investigation has revealed.

The fake company directors are paid to put their names to official paperwork, and have dozens of businesses listed on Companies House, but are not involved in running them.

Two undercover reporters, themselves Kurdish, posed as asylum seekers and were told how easy it would be for them to take over and run a shop and make big profits selling illegal vapes and cigarettes.

The BBC has linked more than 100 mini-marts, barbershops and car washes, operating from Dundee to south Devon, to the crime network. 

But a financial crime investigator told the BBC he believes it goes much wider.

The Home Office said it will investigate the BBC's findings.

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

For more news, analysis and features visit: www.bbc.com/news 

#BBCNews

sample.title: Crime fixer caught by BBC offering to erase ¬£60k fines on migrant workers | BBC News
sample.description:
A man at the centre of an organised crime network has been secretly filmed telling BBC undercover reporters how he can help to erase fines of up to ¬£60,000 for employing illegal workers.

The self-described "accountant" is among a group of Kurdish men, first exposed in a BBC investigation on Tuesday, who enable migrants to work illegally in mini-marts, by registering the businesses in their own name.

The man, who goes by the name of Shaxawan, told the two journalists that he and his associates could help migrants - including asylum seekers - to set up businesses illegally and "confuse" immigration enforcement.

Operating from a solicitor's office in Huddersfield, he said he had "customers in every city".

Subscribe here: http://bit.ly/1rbfUog

sample.title: Deadly typhoon heads for Vietnam after killing at least 114 in Philippines | BBC News
sample.description:
Typhoon Kalmaegi is heading for central Vietnam after leaving a trail of destruction in the Philippines.

The storm, which has killed at least 114 people and submerged entire towns in the Philippines, has strengthened in intensity.

Vietnam - already battling record rains and floods - is now bracing for one of Asia's strongest typhoons this year.

sample.title: Why are prisoners being mistakenly released from UK prisons? | BBC Newscast
sample.description:
News that two prisoners were wrongly released broke after the UK Conservatives' James Cartlidge pressed deputy PM David Lammy on whether any asylum seekers had been mistakenly released since Hadush Kebatu last month.

Adam and Chris chat to home affairs commentator Danny Shaw about what we know about their release and the individuals, and what the political ramifications might be.

Then Adam speaks to Sir Charlie Mayfield, lead reviewer of the Keep Britain Working and former Chairman of the UK's John Lewis Partnership to discuss his review into ill-health and employment.

We talk about his plans to get employees, employers and the Government working together to prevent economic inactivity due to people not working for health reasons.
